bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 16, 1875

div1.p: Reed reassures Emilie Lawrence of his devotion. He learns she is unhappy, but does not know why.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 16, 1875
div1.p:
Your letter,
dated, “Oakland” Aug. 13th, has
just been opened and read,
and although I have already
despatched my customary
Monday's letter, yet I cannot
resist the spell that bids
me write, at once. And, now,
my darling, let me forever
settle that “good-bye”. I
meant not one word that I
used, in my rhyming letter,
*Except the lines which referred to my hasty depar-
ture in order to hide my tears- Those were true.
concerning my departure, &
your behaviour on that oc-
casion-* I was at a loss
with what to fill up my let-
ter & it occurred to me that
I would say a few words,
in the purest fun- I would
have uttered my regrets at
the time of leaving you, but
as I had, time & again, given
utterance to them (which you
cannot have forgotten) I
did not consider that a
repetition of them was nec-
essary- Besides, my darling,
I well knew that, tossed as
my bosom was with emo-
tion, any attempt, on my
part, to give expression to
my feelings would have
resulted in an utter
failure. Although, at other
times, able to maintain a
calm exterior, I should have
been instantly deserted by
my usual serenity. Don't
say, “it is too bad that we can't
understand each other”- We
can understand each other-
We do understand each other.
And all the “good-byes” of
Time & Eternity cannot dim
this understanding “one jot
or tittle”.

But it was not the fore-
going words that caused
me to write, this morning.
Another part of your letter
alarmed me more than
I can tell you! My dar-
ling, little E., what has oc-
curred? And of so se-
rious a nature that you can't
disclose it to the best & true-
est friend on earth! Oh! my
precious child, what can it
be that constrains you to ex-
claim, “that the dearest friend,
yea, even a brother may turn
against us”? You underscore
the word “brother”- This, in con-
nection with the fact that you
are staying at Mrs. Harrolds,
leads to think that you have
had some disagreement with
the doctor- Can it be? Or am
I wrong in my conclusion?- I
trust I am, & yet something
tells me that I am right-
I hasten to ask, am I the
cause of this trouble? If you
love me, Emilie, tell me, at
once, I beseech you, whether
I am, in the remotest manner, con-
nected with your recent trouble. unhappiness.
Do not keep this from me, I beg of
you- Remember that nothing can
possibly occur to separate you
from me but your own wordesire;
& that would be my death-knell!
Ah! my darling Emilie, my whole
heart goes out to you -- my
deepest sympathies are with
you! Would to God that I
could stand between you
& the “angry billows” that
assail you! I would count
it an honor, yea, more
than an honor- A joy to
receive the blows that
threaten you! Gladly would
I welcome the horrors of
the dungeon than that one
sigh should escape your
sweet breast! Oft have
I, on bended knee (and God is
my witness) vowed that the
one great object of my life
should be to keep all care
from you, my darling, & to love
you with my whole mind &
strength- And, as God is my
Helper, this vow, this holy
vow, shall be scrupulously
fulfilled! Whatever the circum-
stances, or the consequences,
you have but to express
the desire, & all my time &
talents are unreservedly
yours-

Trusting that e're my
letter reaches you, your mind
may be freed of all anxiety,
div1.closer:
I remain,
more than ever,
yours fondly & devotedly, Walter.
P.S. The silver wire was found without
the least trouble- As soon as I can
hear from Dr Torney, who has promised
to accompany me when I select the
ring, I will go to N.Y. & forward
it- W.
